usage: A container that opens to reveal storage space for holding items
interactionDeduction: Users grasp the small brass handle on the front with a power grip of the whole hand or a three-finger hook grip, then lift the lid by rotating the wrist upward on its hinge. The motion involves forearm supination and elbow flexion. Once the lid is open, the chest remains stationary while users may support it with their free hand when rummaging inside. The wood-and-metal build gives it moderate weight; the lid has perceived inertia and stops at its hinge limit, providing a hard stop when fully opened.

usage: Players would pick it up, hold it, pose it, and engage in imaginative play scenarios.
interactionDeduction: Because the plush doll is light and compressible, users pick it up between thumb and fingers with a gentle precision grip around the torso or head. They may squeeze or pivot it in mid-air, shake it playfully, or position its limbs with small pinching gestures. The object visually yields slightly but always springs back, encouraging repeated soft squeezes and rapid pose changes.

usage: Optical viewing device for magnifying distant objects
interactionDeduction: Players wrap both hands around the optical barrels using two symmetrical power grips, thumbs resting on top while index fingers hover near focus wheels. Hands are raised to eye level with elbow flexion and slight wrist pronation. Users may roll the focus wheels with fingertip precision, then tilt their head and arms to scan the environment. The binoculars feel moderately heavy and resist rapid lateral acceleration, simulating real glass lenses inside.

usage: This dropper would be used for precise liquid dispensing
interactionDeduction: The narrow glass tube is held with a precision pinch between thumb and index, typically near the rubber bulb. Users squeeze the bulb using thumb-index compression to intake or expel fluid, then aim the tip by rotating the wrist for precise droplet placement. The bulb visually deforms with pressure, springs back on release, and the dropper remains almost weightless, emphasizing finger dexterity rather than arm strength.

usage: This pistol would be used for shooting mechanics in VR scenarios
interactionDeduction: Users employ a single-hand firearm grip: palm wraps the grip frame, index finger rests on the trigger, remaining fingers curl around the handle, and thumb stabilizes the other side. They raise the arm, align sights by rotating forearm and wrist, then squeeze the trigger with a short index-finger pull. The gun delivers a brief recoil impulse—slight upward kick and vibration—requiring users to re-stabilize their wrist for the next shot.

usage: This wheel would be used for vehicle navigation
interactionDeduction: Players grasp opposite sides of the rim (10-and-2 o’clock) with two power grips, elbows bent. They rotate the wheel about its central axis through forearm pronation/supination and shoulder movement. Users might hand-over-hand for large turns, briefly releasing and re-gripping farther along the rim. The wheel resists motion with simulated vehicle steering force that recenters slowly when released.

usage: This virtual double slider serves as a mechanical control interface
interactionDeduction: The red cylindrical handle is pinched or loosely power-gripped by one hand, then translated linearly along two parallel slots. Players push or pull it forward/backward using shoulder and elbow extension while maintaining a straight wrist. The mechanism gives light detent clicks at discrete positions, offering low inertia and slight friction to mimic hardware sliders used in machinery or mixing boards.

usage: This virtual slingshot serves as a projectile launching tool for target practice
interactionDeduction: Users wrap fingers around the vertical grip with a power grip. With the other hand, they pinch the pouch (imaginary band) pulling it straight back by extending the elbow and abducting the shoulder. Tension builds visually as the band stretches. Releasing the pouch with a rapid finger opening launches the projectile; the grip hand experiences a small counter-jerk as the bands snap forward.

usage: Striking and smashing objects
interactionDeduction: The long handle is seized near its end with a firm power grip. Users raise the tool overhead or sideways by flexing the shoulder and elbow, then accelerate the hammer head toward a target through a controlled arc, using wrist snap for added speed. Upon virtual impact, the head stops abruptly, delivering strong force feedback while the user feels a recoil vibration up the handle.

usage: Kitchen serving utensil for scooping, and stirring liquids like soup or stew
interactionDeduction: Players grasp the thin handle somewhere mid-length with a relaxed power grip or pinch grip near the upper shaft. They dip the bowl into imaginary liquid via wrist pronation and elbow extension, lift, then pour by tilting the wrist so the bowl mouth points downward. Gentle stirring involves circular wrist motions; the long handle provides leverage with minimal resistance.

usage: This virtual button would be used for triggering critical actions
interactionDeduction: Users reach out with an extended index finger and deliver a straight downward press onto the button top. The contact is momentary; finger joints flex slightly as they push until the button bottoms out with an audible click. The button cap depresses about 1 cm, offers moderate spring resistance, then pops back up when the finger lifts, confirming activation.

usage: Resting against the tree, using it as back support
interactionDeduction: Players lean their avatar’s back or shoulder against the trunk, transferring body weight through broad torso contact. The interaction is static and sustained; minor posture shifts slide clothing against rough bark. The tree remains completely immovable, providing a rigid, cool, and textured vertical surface for resting.

usage: These party balloons would be used for playful interaction in celebration VR environments. VR players would flick or tap floating balloons to set them in motion.
interactionDeduction: Users lightly tap or flick the balloon surfaces with fingertips or the back of the hand. Contact is quick and gentle, imparting small impulses that send the balloons drifting away. Because of low virtual mass, they wobble and ascend or bob erratically. Players may also bat them with an open palm for longer pushes, feeling almost no resistance.

usage: This potted plant would be used for gentle, therapeutic interaction. VR players would run their hands along the leaves for stress relief.
interactionDeduction: Players slowly run their open hand over the top foliage, fingers splaying and bending to brush individual leaves. The motion is gentle and exploratory with light fingertip contact. Leaves bend and spring back, offering soft resistance, while the heavy clay pot at the base stays fixed, reinforcing a stable anchor point.

usage: This desktop globe would be used for educational exploration in classroom. VR players would rotate the sphere to navigate around the world.
interactionDeduction: Users place an open palm or several fingertips against the sphere, then apply sideways force while maintaining contact, resulting in a smooth rotational spin about its tilted axis. Small pushes yield slow rotation; stronger swipes accelerate the globe. Friction gradually slows it, encouraging repeated spins and stops for geographic inspection.

usage: This scarecrow punching bag would be used for combat training, exercise, or stress relief in VR fitness, martial arts, or outdoor training environments. VR players would strike it with fists, hands, or potentially legs to practice techniques.
interactionDeduction: Players strike the padded torso and head areas with closed fists, open-hand palm strikes, or elbow/leg kicks. Movements involve full-body kinetic chains—hip rotation, shoulder extension, and quick arm acceleration—followed by brief impact and recoil. The target compresses slightly and swings or pivots on its support rod, providing visual feedback of absorbed force.

usage: This soccer ball would be used for training exercises. VR players would primarily kick the ball for practicing penalties
interactionDeduction: Users approach and kick the ball with the instep or toe of a virtual foot through a forward leg swing. Contact is momentary, occurring at peak foot velocity. The ball accelerates away on a realistic trajectory; heavier kicks send it farther, while taps nudge it slightly. Players may also stop it by placing a foot atop and rolling it with plantar pressure.

usage: Musical performance. VR players would press the piano keys to generate musical notes
interactionDeduction: Players extend individual fingers to press down specific piano keys. Each key press involves a short downward stroke (~10 mm) with minimal force, followed by an automatic spring return. Rapid sequential finger lifts and drops enable chords and melodies. The frame remains stationary while only the targeted keys depress and release with audible note feedback.

usage: VR players would primarily sit in the chair for work, relaxation, or social interactions
interactionDeduction: Users back up and lower their avatar’s pelvis until contact with the seat pan, bending knees and hips. Once seated, weight is supported across the thighs and buttocks in sustained contact. The chair is stable and unmoving; users can lean against the curved backrest or shift posture, causing small frictional slides but no perceptible chair displacement.

usage: VR players would run their hands across the sculptural surfaces to appreciate the craftsmanship
interactionDeduction: Players glide fingers along the contours of the marble-like sculpture, tracing facial features and flowing hair. Contact is light and exploratory, mainly fingertip strokes with occasional palm rests. The bust is rigid, cool, and smooth, offering no movement but allowing tactile appreciation of carved ridges and planes.
